Design and optimization of CuCo-LDO catalysts via ZIF-67 sacrificial templates for enhanced toluene oxidation: A comprehensive study on morphology, structure, and catalytic activity Yang Xu Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Jinghuan Chen Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources ⁎ Zhiping Ye Writing – review & editing Supervision Jiade Wang Supervision Resources Funding acquisition Key Laboratory of Microbial Technology for Industrial Pollution Control, College of Environment, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310014, China Key Laboratory of Microbial Technology for Industrial Pollution Control, College of Environment Zhejiang University of Technology Hangzhou 310014 China Key Laboratory of Microbial Technology for Industrial Pollution Control, College of Environment, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310014, China ⁎ Corresponding author. The investigation into the development of an active transition-metal oxide catalyst with controllable morphology for the degradation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) is a subject of considerable importance and warrants further exploration. In this study, ZIF-67 was prepared and employed as a sacrificial template, with varying quantities of Cu ions incorporated to synthesize layered copper-cobalt double oxide (CuCo-LDO) featuring a modifiable surface state. A comprehensive characterization of the CuCo-LDO catalysts was conducted, encompassing structural properties, morphology, surface chemical state, and redox properties, utilizing a range of analytical techniques. Subsequent evaluations included testing the catalytic activity for toluene oxidation and assessing stability performance. The results revealed that differing Cu contents played a pivotal role in inducing changes in the morphology and structure of CuCo-LDO, thereby significantly influencing its oxidation activity towards toluene. Notably, the flower-like structure of 3CuCo-LDO (Cu% = 20.14 wt.%) exhibited outstanding toluene oxidation activity attributable to its unique structure and composition. This research contributes novel insights to the design of highs-performance catalysts targeting volatile organic compounds. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords ZIF-67 CuCo-LDO Volatile organic compounds Catalytic oxidation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) pose significant hazards, both for the environment and human health. In the atmospheric environment, certain VOCs can contribute to photochemical reactions, generating secondary pollutants [1]. Moreover, VOCs can ascend to the stratosphere, potentially causing harm to the ozone layer [2]. From a human health perspective, VOCs have the capacity to irritate the eyes, nasal passages, and respiratory mucosa [3]. Technologies for VOCs abatement can be broadly categorized into recovery and destruction methods. Recovery technologies encompass absorption, adsorption, membrane separation, and condensation, while destruction methods include thermal oxidation, catalytic oxidation, and biological oxidation. Among these, catalytic oxidation has gained significant attention due to its high efficiency and low toxicity. Cobalt-based metal oxides have been widely investigated and have demonstrated remarkable catalytic efficacy in various catalytic reactions. More recently, cobalt-containing metal oxides have often been obtained through the direct thermal decomposition of precursors, such as layered double hydroxides (LDH). LDHs, characterized by the general formula, consist of divalent metal cations (M2+), trivalent metal cations (M3+), and interlayer anions (e.g., NO3 −, CO3 2−, SO4 2−, surfactants, or other ligands) [4]. Common methods for LDH preparation include co-precipitation, hydrothermal synthesis, and ion exchange [5,6]. While these methods yield crystals with uniform compositions, they often fall short in controlling catalyst morphology, crystallite size, and specific surface area. The structure and morphology of a catalyst play a pivotal role in determining its catalytic efficiency [7]. The development of LDH catalytic materials with controllable morphologies, such as layered, mesostructured, and porous structures, is essential for enhancing catalyst performance [8]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have garnered extensive attention in the field of catalysis [9–11]. These studies have synthesized MOFs with specific morphologies, highlighting the potential for preparing LDHs with tailored morphologies using MOFs as templates to enhance their catalytic performance. The zeolitic imidazolate framework (e.g., ZIF-67 and ZIF-8) is an ideal template due to its tunable chemistry and chemical stability. For instance, Li et al. [12] designed a hollow Co-Ni-LDH structure utilizing ZIF as a template. The resulting calcined product, layered double oxide (LDO) exhibited exceptional catalytic activity in CO oxidation. Chen et al. [13] directly prepared Co-LDH catalysts in nanocage form via the solvothermal method using ZIF-67 as the precursor. These as-synthesized Co-LDHs displayed efficient electrocatalytic activity for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) based on their well-structured assembly. While metal oxides derived from ZIFs have been widely studied in the context of CO oxidation and electrocatalysis, there is limited research on the utilization of hollow layered double oxide catalysts, prepared with ZIF-67 as a template, in the catalytic oxidation of toluene. Furthermore, CuO and Cu-based catalysts, being common transition metal oxides, have rarely been doped into Co3O4 during the synthesis of LDO and LDH. Given the strong synergy between these two components, we anticipate that a Cu-Co composite bimetallic oxide may yield enhanced catalytic performance. In this study, we employed ZIF-67 as a template to synthesize catalysts using a straightforward method. Initially, a range of CuCo-LDHs was prepared by introducing varying quantities of copper nitrate. These synthesized LDH products were subsequently oxidized in ambient air to yield layered Cu-Co double oxides. The physicochemical properties of these catalysts and their performance in catalytic oxidation of toluene were comprehensively investigated. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation ZIF-67 was synthesized in according with previously published protocols [14]. Copper nitrate trihydrate (Aladdin, 99 %) was accurately weighed in varying amounts (1.5 mg, 6.0 mg, 24.0 mg, 48.0 mg) and individually dispersed in 50 mL of methanol. The resulting solutions were then placed in a water bath at 85 ℃, followed by the addition of 80 mg of ZIF-67. The mixture was subsequently refluxed with continuous stirring for a duration of 3 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting precipitate was harvested through centrifugation, followed by a thorough wash with methanol. The collected precipitate was then dried overnight at 60 ℃, yielding xCuCo-LDH (x = 1, 2, 3, 4) catalysts. The final step involved calcination at 350 ℃ for 2 h in a tube furnace, producing xCuCo-LDO (x = 1, 2, 3, 4). To facilitate a comparative analysis, the same synthesis procedure was employed. In this case, 302.0 mg of copper nitrate trihydrate (Aladdin, 99 %) was dispersed in 50 mL of methanol. Subsequently, 410.5 mg of 2-methylimidazole (Aladdin, 98 %) was added to the solution. The mixture underwent reflux under identical conditions in a water bath for 3 h, culminating in the acquisition of the Cu-LDH sample through centrifugation, washing, and drying. CuO was obtained by subjecting the sample to calcination at 350 ℃ for 2 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a PANalytical X'Pert PRO powder diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.1541 nm). The instrument operated at a voltage of 40 kV and a current of 40 mA. Data collection occurred over a 2θ range from 5° to 80° at a scanning rate of 6°/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments were carried out employing an Escalab 250Xi instrument. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy was performed using a Bruker VERTEX 70 spectrometer. N2 adsorption-desorption analysis was conducted using a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 instrument. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FETEM) was employed with a Nano nova 450 device, operating at a voltage of 15 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) were executed on a JEM-2100 microscope equipped with an EDX detector, with the acceleration voltage set at 200 kV. The H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were conducted using a Micromeritics AutoChem 2910 instrument. Prior to each test, a 30 mg sample underwent pretreatment at 250 ℃ for 1 h in an argon flow of 30 mL/min, followed by cooling to room temperature. Subsequently, the sample was heated up to 600 ℃ in a 5 vol.% H2/Ar flow, with a heating rate of 10 ℃/min. Additionally, O2-temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) experiments were also carried out using the same instrument. After the same pretreatment as in H2-TPR, the sample was treated firstly for 30 min at 50 ℃ in a 5 vol.% O2/Ar flow of 30 mL/min. Then the sample was heated up to 950 ℃ in a 5 vol.% O2/Ar flow, with a heating rate of 10 ℃/min. 2.3 Catalytic activity assessment The catalytic activity of the samples was evaluated within a fixed-bed quartz tubular reactor. Initially, 200 mg of catalyst (crushed, 40–60 mesh) was loaded into the quartz tube. Toluene vapor was generated by passing a N2 flow through a bottle containing pure toluene in a low-temperature thermostatic bath. The total flow rate of the toluene and dry air mixture was meticulously controlled at 80 mL/min. This mixture comprised 1000 ppm of toluene and 20 % oxygen, with nitrogen serving as the balance gas, resulting in a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) set at 24,000 mL·g−1·h−1. Subsequently, the temperature was ramped up from room temperature to 120 ℃ at a controlled rate of 2.5 ℃/min and held steady for a duration of 2 h. At specific temperature intervals, typically every 15 ℃, the temperature was increased and maintained for 30 min upon reaching each pre-set temperature point. The concentration of toluene in the mixture was quantified using a GC-6820 gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector. Toluene conversion was determined using the following formula: X toluene = C toluene ( in ) − C toluene ( out ) C toluene ( in ) × 100 % Where: Ctoluene (in) (ppm): Inlet toluene concentration Ctoluene (out) (ppm): Outlet toluene concentration The study identified the reaction temperature required to achieve 50 % and 90 % conversion of toluene. 3 Results 3.1 Structure analysis The XRD patterns of all samples are presented in Fig. 1 . Fig. 1A reveals that the diffraction peaks of ZIF-67 at 7.3°, 10.4°, 12.8°, 14.6°, 16.3°, 18.0°, and 26.6° align with the standard card, corresponding to the (110), (002), (112), (022), (013), (222), and (134) crystal planes. This observation unequivocally verifies the successful synthesis of ZIF-67 [15]. Furthermore, all the XRD patterns for 1CuCo-LDH, 2CuCo-LDH, 3CuCo-LDH, and Cu-LDH display distinct diffraction peaks characteristic of LDH. These patterns can be attributed to Co(OH)2 (PDF 74–1057) and Cu2(OH)3NO3 (PDF 03–0061) species. Fig. 1B illustrates the XRD patterns of the respective oxides obtained after the aforementioned materials underwent calcination in air for 2 h. In these patterns, the diffraction peaks at 19.0°, 31.3°, 36.8°, 44.8°, 55.6°, 59.3°, 65.2°, and 77.3° are ascribed to Co3O4 (JCPDS 74–2120). Additionally, diffraction peaks at 32.5°, 35.5°, 38.7°, 46.2°, 48.7°, 54.3°, 58.4°, 61.5°, 66.2°, 68.1°, 72.4°, and 75.1° are evident in the XRD patterns. These peaks are readily indexed to the CuO phase (JCPDS 80–1917). Notably, there is a lack of conspicuous diffraction peaks of CuO in the XRD patterns of 1CuCo-LDO and 2CuCo-LDO samples, likely attributed to the relatively low Cu content or enhanced dispersion in these samples. In contrast, the XRD pattern of the 3CuCo-LDO sample unmistakably displays diffraction peaks at 35.5° and 38.7°, confirming the presence of CuO. Table 1 provides insight into the lattice parameters of Co3O4, which slightly increased from 8.095 Å to 8.101 Å following the introduction of copper species. This observation can be attributed to the larger ionic radius of Cu2+ compared to Co3+, serving as conclusive evidence of successful Cu ion incorporation into the Co3O4 crystals. Furthermore, crystallite size calculations were derived from the Co3O4 (311) diffraction peaks using the Scherrer equation. The results indicate that the addition of Cu ions effectively inhibits crystal growth, as evidenced by the reduction in Co3O4 particle size with increasing Cu content [16]. To ascertain the chemical identity of CuCo-LDH, the FT-IR spectra of all uncalcined samples are presented in Fig. 1C. In comparison to established data for ZIF-67, it is evident that we have successfully synthesized ZIF-67 [17]. Notably, two distinct bands observed at 2925 cm−1 and 3135 cm−1 in all three CuCo-LDH samples can be attributed to the CH vibration of the methyl group and the aromatic ring of 2-methylimidazolate [18]. Moreover, the presence of hydroxyl groups and interlayer water in the tested samples is reflected by the peaks in the range of 3400–3650 cm−1 [19]. In addition, a narrow band at 1384 cm−1, associated with the stretching vibration of NO3 − [20], is consistent across all samples, further confirming the successful synthesis of CuCo-LDH and Cu-LDH. Based on the evidence presented in XRD and FT-IR spectra, the utilization of ZIF-67 as a template facilitated the successful preparation of CuCo-LDH and its corresponding oxides. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and BJH pore size distributions of the five samples after calcination are presented in Fig. 1D and 1E. As depicted in Fig. 1D, all the catalysts displayed IV isotherms with characteristic H3-type hysteresis loops, underscoring the presence of mesopores in each of the samples. This observation is further corroborated by the pore size distribution data in Fig. 1E. Moreover, Table 1 provides additional insights. The introduction of Cu into the catalysts resulted in a notable decrease in specific surface area, ranging from 64.2 to 52.5 m2·g−1, while pure CuO exhibited a significantly lower specific surface area of only 10.2 m2·g−1. Meanwhile, the average pore size and pore volume decreased with increasing Cu content. This discrepancy underscores the influence of metal oxides with higher Cu content, which promotes the formation of larger aggregates, albeit at the cost of partial pore blockage and a subsequent reduction in specific surface area [21]. In general, the larger specific surface area of Cu-Co oxides yields superior catalytic performance when compared to pure CuO samples. 3.2 Morphological and structural analysis The morphology of the synthesized samples was characterized using FESEM and TEM. As illustrated in Fig. 2 a1, ZIF-67 presented as a rhombic dodecahedron with an approximate particle size of 800 nm. Following calcination in air, Co3O4 exhibited a discernible core-shell structure while retaining the overall shape of ZIF-67 (Fig. 2a2). However, as the content of Cu ions increased, the surface of ZIF-67 underwent gradual etching by the Cu particles, resulting in the transformation of its morphology (Table 1, Fig. 2b1 and 2c1). When the Cu content reached 20.14 wt.%, the formation of the distinctive flower-like 3CuCo-LDH structure became evident (Fig. 2d1), a product of self-assembly involving leaf-like structures. Additionally, the corresponding LDO maintained its flower-like morphology. Cu-LDH, on the other hand, exhibited irregular particles with a size range of 20–80 nm, and the morphology of CuO after calcination closely resembled that of Cu-LDH. For a more detailed comparison, we prepared a catalyst with a higher copper content (40.54 %). The FESEM images of the sample were illustrated in Fig. S1, revealing that the morphology before and after calcination closely resembles those of 3CuCo-LDO. High-resolution TEM images of Co3O4 (Fig. 2a5) revealed well-defined (111) and (311) crystal planes of the Co3O4 phase, with corresponding interplanar spacings of 0.46 nm and 0.24 nm. This structural feature was consistently observed in all cobalt-containing samples, including CuCo-LDH and CuCo-LDO, as indicated by (111) planes with lattice fringes of 0.46 nm (Fig. 2b5, 2d5). Moreover, HRTEM images of CuO and xCuCo-LDO (Fig. 2e5 and 2b5–2d5) exhibited lattice fringes measuring 0.23 nm, corresponding to the (111) crystal plane of CuO. These observations provided further evidence of the successful formation of CuCo-LDO. The elemental compositions of the samples were analyzed using energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), and the results were summarized in Table 1. The data in Table 1 revealed the presence of Cu and Co elements in all the catalysts, with the Cu content increasing from 0.25 wt.% to 20.14 wt.%. A representative EDS image (3CuCo-LDO) is presented in Fig. S2A, further confirming the coexistence of the two metal oxides. Moreover, the elemental mapping of the 3CuCo-LDO sample, displayed in Fig. S2B, illustrates the uniform distribution of Cu, Co, and O elements within its flower-like structure. To reveal the growth process of the flower-like 3CuCo-LDO, time-dependent experiments were implemented and the SEM images of the products obtained at different reaction times were shown in Fig. S3. The process commenced with the corrosion of the ZIF-67 framework by Cu2+ ions (Fig. S1a and S1b), leading to the gradual release of Co3+ ions from the ZIF-67 structure [22]. Subsequently, imidazole molecules underwent facile decomposition in an alcoholic solution under elevated temperature, generating an alkaline environment concomitant with the formation of OH− ions [13]. In this context, free metal cations, including Cu2+ and Co3+, readily combined with anions, such as NO3 − and OH−, to form Cu-Co nanosheets (Fig. S3c). Ultimately, the flower-like 3CuCo-LDH material emerged through the self-assembly of these nanosheets (Fig. S3d–f), while the application of heat treatment in air resulted in the formation of CuCo-LDO. 3.3 Surface chemical analysis To elucidate the surface chemical states and species of the catalyst, we conducted XPS analysis. As displayed in Fig. 3A , the O 1 s spectra of all samples were deconvoluted into three distinct peaks: the lowest energy peak, situated at 529.7 − 530.0 eV, was attributed to lattice oxygen (Olat); the peak at 531.3 − 531.7 eV was likely associated with oxygen adsorbed on the surface (Oads); and the highest binding energy peak, at 533.3 - 533.5 eV, corresponded to surface oxygen existing in the form of adsorbed carbonate or adsorbed water molecules (Osur) [23]. As reported in literature, oxygen species present on the surface (Osur and Oads) played pivotal roles in catalytic oxidation reaction [24]. The molar ratios of (Osur + Oads)/Olat for all the catalysts are summarized in Table 2 . Remarkably, the flower-like 3CuCo-LDO sample exhibited the highest (Osur + Oads)/Olat ratio among all the samples, suggesting its superior catalytic activity. Moving to Fig. 3B, the Co 2p spectra of Co3O4, 1CuCo-LDO, 2CuCo-LDO, 3CuCo-LDO were deconvoluted into two prominent main peaks (D1 and D2). The peaks at 781.2 ± 0.2 and 796.1 ± 0.2 eV were attributed to Co3+, while those at 779.7 ± 0.2 [25] and 794.7 ± 0.2 eV signified Co2+ [26,27]. It is widely acknowledged that Co3+ plays a pivotal role in the catalytic oxidation process [28]. Consequently, we calculated the Co3+/Co2+ ratio in the cobalt-containing oxides, as presented in Table 2. Notably, the results revealed that 3CuCo-LDO possessed the highest molar ratio of Co3+/Co2+. This might imply that the 3CuCo-LDO catalyst exhibits higher catalytic performance. Additionally, the Cu 2p spectrum of the copper-containing catalyst is depicted in Fig. 3C. All samples exhibited two main peaks at 935.2 ± 0.2 eV and 954.1 ± 0.2 eV, respectively [29]. In the case of the aforementioned catalysts, particularly 3CuCo-LDO and CuO, satellite peaks were observed around 942.3 eV, providing evidence for the presence of Cu2+ or CuO. 3.4 Reduction performance analysis To further explore the reduction performance of the catalysts, we conducted H2-TPR tests. The H2-TPR profiles are shown in Fig. 4 . In the case of pure Co3O4, the H2-TPR profile displayed two distinctive reduction peaks at 273 ℃ and 367 ℃ (Fig. 4): the narrower, initial peak (α) was attributed to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ [30], while the subsequent peak (β) denoted the reduction of Co2+ to metallic Co [31]. Notably, the strong reduction peak observed at 246 ℃ in the CuO reduction curve was indicative of the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu0 [32]. Regarding the CuCo-LDO samples, the position of the reduction peaks (α and β) gradually shifted to lower temperatures with an increase in Cu content. It is evident that the 3CuCo-LDO sample exhibited the most favorable reducibility, and the reduction peak of the 3CuCo-LDO catalyst occurred at the lowest temperature. This signifies that an appropriate level of Cu ion doping could enhance the catalyst's reduction performance. Furthermore, we quantified the H2 consumption of all catalysts, and the results are summarized in Table 2. The data revealed that, as the Cu content increased, hydrogen consumption of the α peak progressively rose, consistent with earlier findings. However, total hydrogen consumption decreased at higher temperatures with an increase in Cu content, likely due to the accumulation of Cu species on the catalyst surface, which may impede the reduction of metal oxides [33]. 3.5 Surface oxygen species analysis In order to investigate the oxygen species and their surface components on the solid catalysts, we conducted O2-TPR tests, and the results are presented in Fig. 5 . Peaks within the range of 50–150 ℃ for all samples were attributed to the desorption of molecular oxygen (O2) [34]. Meanwhile, peaks within the range of 200–450 ℃ were ascribed to surface adsorbed oxygen (O2 −, O −) [35]. Furthermore, the peaks observed above 700 ℃ in Fig. 5B were attributed to the desorption of lattice oxygen (O2 −) [36], with the noteworthy observation that these peaks shifted to lower temperatures with increasing Cu content. This shift indicated that the desorption of lattice oxygen species occurred more readily in Cu-Co composites compared to Co3O4 and CuO samples [34,37]. The quantities of oxygen desorption for all catalysts are summarized in Table 2. Notably, the 3CuCo-LDO sample exhibited the highest release of oxygen within the 200–450 ℃ range, signifying an abundance of adsorbed oxygen species. This observation aligns with the XPS results and is in accordance with previous research, which has suggested that high concentrations of surface adsorbed oxygen are conducive to oxidation reactions [38]. 3.6 Catalytic performance analysis The catalytic performance in toluene oxidation over Co3O4, CoCu-LDO, and CuO is displayed in Fig. 6A , and the results are summarized in Table 3 . Throughout the tests, toluene was completely converted into CO2 and H2O. Using T 90 as the standard for activity assessment, the order of activity was as follows: 3CuCo-LDO > 2CuCo-LDO > 1CuCo-LDO > Co3O4 > CuO. This result underscores the improved catalytic activity of the Co-Cu oxide with increasing Cu content. To investigate whether the activity further increases with the higher Cu content, we synthesized a Cu-Co bimetallic oxide catalyst with higher Cu content (40.54 %) and tested its catalytic activity. As shown in Fig. S4, the sample with higher Cu content exhibited inferior activity compared to the 3CuCo-LDO catalyst. These findings emphasize the crucial role of a specific amount of CuO combined with Co3O4 in achieving complete toluene oxidation. Moreover, under identical conditions, the flower-like 3CuCo-LDO catalyst demonstrated superior catalytic oxidation activity for toluene compared to other cobalt-based and copper-based catalysts reported in the literature, as detailed in Table S1. Fig. 6B illustrates an Arrhenius plot for all samples, revealing a strong linear relationship between the natural logarithm of the reaction rate and the reciprocal of temperature (1000/T) for each sample. The apparent activation energies (E a) of these samples were calculated and are listed in Table 3. The order of Ea is consistent with the observed trends in T 90 and T 50. Particularly, 3CuCo-LDO exhibited the lowest activation energy (E a = 85.6 kJ/mol), underlining its superior catalytic activity for toluene oxidation. 4 Discussion In our study, a series of CuCo-LDO catalysts were synthesized using ZIF-67 as a sacrificial template. FT-IR analysis revealed the presence of hydroxide and nitrate groups in the 1CuCo-LDH, 2CuCo-LDH, and 3CuCo-LDH samples, consistent with the XRD results, confirming the successful synthesis of LDHs. Morphological analysis disclosed a progressive chemical etching of ZIF-67 by Cu ions with increasing Cu content. The higher the copper nitrate content in the solution, the more severe the erosion of the ZIF-67 structure. When the copper nitrate concentration is low, the LDH samples (1CuCo-LDH and 2CuCo-LDH) are essentially spherical. However, as the copper nitrate concentration continues to increase, the ZIF-67 framework is completely destroyed, and the LDH exhibits a flower-like structure assembled from nanosheets. After calcination in air, these LDH samples transformed into the corresponding LDOs. The TEM images of 1CuCo-LDO and 2CuCo-LDO displayed layered structures, indicating that the etching process begins from the outer layer of ZIF-67, gradually extending towards the interior of the ZIF-67 particles. The TEM image of the 3CoCu-LDO sample demonstrated the complete chemical etching of ZIF-67, resulting in the formation of sheet-like Cu-Co composites. HR-TEM imaging confirmed the presence of lattice fringes corresponding to Co3O4 and CuO, providing evidence for the formation of Cu-Co composite oxides. Elemental mapping revealed a uniform distribution of Co and Cu elements within the sample. The interaction between Co3O4 and CuO in the flower-like CuCo-LDH was found to underpin its superior catalytic performance in toluene oxidation. The interaction between oxides in binary composite oxide catalysts plays a crucial role in catalytic activity, as validated in numerous catalyst systems and reactions [39,40]. In this study, the unique layered structure provides abundant surface area and pore volume, creating conditions for additional phase contact interfaces [41,42]. This facilitates the adsorption and activation of gaseous reactants on the catalyst surface, leading to their complete oxidation. The H2-TPR curves clearly demonstrated that 3CuCo-LDO had the lowest reduction peak temperature, a result of the interaction between Co3O4 and CuO. XPS analysis revealed the coexistence of cobalt and copper ions with different valences on the catalyst surface. Notably, the flower-like 3CuCo-LDO sample exhibited the highest Co3+/Co2+ ratio, a factor conducive to enhancing reactivity. This interaction likely contributed to the exceptional performance of the catalyst. XRD analysis of the calcined product revealed an increase in the lattice parameter of Co3O4 upon the incorporation of Cu, confirming the successful integration of Cu ions into the Co3O4 lattice. The introduction of foreign ions into the lattice may induce lattice distortion, consequently resulting in the formation of oxygen vacancies [43,44]. These vacancies serve as sites for the adsorption and activation of oxygen molecules facilitating the generation of reactive oxygen species such as O2 −, O − and peroxide ions O2 2− [45,46], which play pivotal roles in the catalytic oxidation of toluene. Thus, elevating the concentration of oxygen vacancies can enhance the production of reactive oxygen species, thereby boosting catalytic activity, which has been well-demonstrated in various studies [47,48]. In our study, the addition of an appropriate amount of Cu led to a progressive increase in the relative amount of surface oxygen vacancies, as indicated by XPS results. Additionally, O2-TPD results confirmed a continuous increase in the quantity of surface adsorbed oxygen species (O2 −, O −) within the temperature range of 200−450 °C as the Cu content increased. Therefore, appropriate Cu doping resulted in the generation of a greater number of oxygen vacancies and reactive oxygen species, thereby enhancing the catalytic oxidation activity for toluene. 5 Conclusions In this investigation, we successfully synthesized CuCo-LDO catalysts using ZIF-67 sacrificial templating. Modulating the copper nitrate content induced a morphological transition, converting LDH samples from spherical to flower-like structures. Subsequent calcination validated this transformation into LDOs, as confirmed by XRD and TEM imaging. The catalytic activity in toluene oxidation revealed a nuanced trend in Cu-Co composite oxides, with an initial rise and subsequent decline correlated with increasing Cu content. Notably, the nanoflower-like 3CuCo-LDO, containing 20.14 wt.% Cu, emerged as the optimal catalyst, exhibiting a T 90 of 232 °C and the lowest activation energy (E a = 85.6 kJ/mol). This highlights the catalytic potential of a judiciously balanced CuO and Co3O4 combination. The interaction between Co3O4 and CuO in the flower-like CuCo-LDH significantly influenced its superior catalytic performance in toluene oxidation. The XRD analysis verified Cu ion integration into the Co3O4 lattice, inducing lattice distortion and oxygen vacancies. The flower-like 3CuCo-LDO demonstrated the highest concentration of active oxygen species, corroborated by O2-TPD results, highlighting their pivotal role in the catalytic oxidation process. The exceptional performance of the flower-like 3CuCo-LDO catalyst can be attributed to several factors, including the interaction between different metals within the sample, the presence of abundant reactive oxygen species, enhanced reducibility, and a higher Co3+ ion content. This work underscores the importance of tailored structures and metal interactions in enhancing catalytic activity for environmental applications. coredata.dc:description: The investigation into the development of an active transition-metal oxide catalyst with controllable morphology for the degradation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) is a subject of considerable importance and warrants further exploration. In this study, ZIF-67 was prepared and employed as a sacrificial template, with varying quantities of Cu ions incorporated to synthesize layered copper-cobalt double oxide (CuCo-LDO) featuring a modifiable surface state. A comprehensive characterization of the CuCo-LDO catalysts was conducted, encompassing structural properties, morphology, surface chemical state, and redox properties, utilizing a range of analytical techniques. Subsequent evaluations included testing the catalytic activity for toluene oxidation and assessing stability performance. The results revealed that differing Cu contents played a pivotal role in inducing changes in the morphology and structure of CuCo-LDO, thereby significantly influencing its oxidation activity towards toluene. Notably, the flower-like structure of 3CuCo-LDO (Cu% = 20.14 wt.%) exhibited outstanding toluene oxidation activity attributable to its unique structure and composition. This research contributes novel insights to the design of highs-performance catalysts targeting volatile organic compounds.
coredata.dc:title: Design and optimization of CuCo-LDO catalysts via ZIF-67 sacrificial templates for enhanced toluene oxidation: A comprehensive study on morphology, structure, and catalytic activity
